sen.j: 小椋神社（おぐらじんじゃ）は滋賀県大津市にある神社。
sen.e: Ogura-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine that exists in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Ogura-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
sen.cmt: that existsをlocatedに変更しました。
sen.e: Ogura-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳に記載された式内社。
sen.e: It is a shikinai-sha (shrines listed in Engishiki laws).
It is a Shikinai-sha listed on Engishiki jimmyocho (a shrine listed on the register of shrines in Japan).
sen.cmt: 延喜式神名帳の訳を追記しました。
sen.e: It is a Shikinai-sha listed on Engishiki jimmyocho (a shrine listed on the register of shrines in Japan).

sen.j: 小椋神社、大宮神社、若宮神社、今宮神社、新宮神社の五社が祀られている。
sen.e: Five shrines of Ogura-jinja Shrine, Omiya-jinja Shrine, Wakamiya-jinja Shrine, Imamiya-jinja Shrine and Shingu-jinja Shrine are enshrined in the precincts..
Five shrines of Ogura-jinja Shrine, Omiya-jinja Shrine, Wakamiya-jinja Shrine, Imamiya-jinja Shrine and Shingu-jinja Shrine are enshrined in the precincts..
Five shrines of Ogura-jinja Shrine, Omiya-jinja Shrine, Wakamiya-jinja Shrine, Imamiya-jinja Shrine and Shingu-jinja Shrine are enshrined in the precincts..

sen.j: 祭神
sen.e: The enshrined deities
The enshrined deities
The enshrined deities

sen.j: 闇淤加美神⇒小椋神社本殿
sen.e: Kuraokami-no-kami is enshrined in the Honden (main shrine) of Ogura-jinja Shrine.
Kuraokami-no-kami is enshrined in the Honden (main shrine) of Ogura-jinja Shrine.
Kuraokami-no-kami is enshrined in the Honden (main shrine) of Ogura-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 伊耶那美命（イザナミ）⇒大宮神社
sen.e: Izanami no mikoto is enshrined in Omiya-jinja Shrine.
Izanami no mikoto is enshrined in Omiya-jinja Shrine.
Izanami no mikoto is enshrined in Omiya-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 稚日女命⇒若宮神社
sen.e: Wakahirume no mikoto is enshrined in Wakamiya-jinja Shrine.
Wakahirume no mikoto is enshrined in Wakamiya-jinja Shrine.
Wakahirume no mikoto is enshrined in Wakamiya-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 大穴持神（大国主）⇒今宮神社
sen.e: Onamochi no kami (Okuninushi) is enshrined in Imamiya-jinja Shrine.
Onamochi no kami (Okuninushi) is enshrined in Imamiya-jinja Shrine.
Onamochi no kami (Okuninushi) is enshrined in Imamiya-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 少彦名神⇒新宮神社
sen.e: Sukunabikona no kami is enshrined in Shingu-jinja Shrine.
Sukunabikona no kami is enshrined in Shingu-jinja Shrine.
Sukunabikona no kami is enshrined in Shingu-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 由緒
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 天安 (日本)2年（858年）の創建と伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that the shrine was built in 858.
It is said that the shrine was built in 858.
It is said that the shrine was built in 858.

sen.j: はじめ文徳天皇の皇子、惟喬親王により大宮神社祀られ、翌年源融により、小椋神社が祀られた。
sen.e: At first Omiya-jinja Shrine was built by Imperial Prince Koretaka of Emperor Montoku, and the next year Ogura-jinja Shrine was built by MINAMOTO no Toru.
At first Omiya-jinja Shrine was built by Imperial Prince Koretaka of Emperor Montoku, and the next year Ogura-jinja Shrine was built by MINAMOTO no Toru.
At first Omiya-jinja Shrine was built by Imperial Prince Koretaka of Emperor Montoku, and the next year Ogura-jinja Shrine was built by MINAMOTO no Toru.

sen.j: 小椋神社は小椋神社奥宮の滝壺神社より現在の地に移された。
sen.e: Ogura-jinja Shrine was moved from Takitsubo-jinja Shrine in okunomiya (interior shrine) of Ogura-jinja Shrine to the current place.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Ogura-jinja Shrine was moved from Takitsubo-jinja Shrine in okunomiya (interior shrine) of Ogura-jinja Shrine to the current place.
Ogura-jinja Shrine was moved from Takitsubo-jinja Shrine in okunomiya (interior shrine) of Ogura-jinja Shrine to the current place.

sen.j: 小椋神社はこれより遡ること約200年前、天智天皇の大津京遷都のおりに同行した加太夫仙人という行者が大和国の丹生川上神社から分霊を仰木の地に移し祀った。
sen.e: The shrine had been built 200 years before by the practitioner called Kadayu sennin (hermit) who accompanied Emperor Tenchi at the time of the transfer of national capital to Otsu by splitting the goshintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) and moving and enshrining it to the place called Ogi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The shrine had been built 200 years before by the practitioner called Kadayu sennin (hermit) who accompanied Emperor Tenji at the time of the transfer of national capital to Otsu by splitting the goshintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) and moving and enshrining it to the place called Ogi.
sen.cmt: 宮内庁HP記載に従い、天智天皇（てんじてんのう）：Emperor Tenjiとしました。
sen.e: The shrine had been built 200 years before by the practitioner called Kadayu sennin (hermit) who accompanied Emperor Tenji at the time of the transfer of national capital to Otsu by splitting the goshintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) and moving and enshrining it to the place called Ogi.

sen.j: その後、延喜2年（902年）若宮神社が、建久元年（1190年）に今宮神社、新宮神社が境内に祀られた。
sen.e: After that, in 902 Wakamiya-jinja Shrine was built and in 1190 Imamiya-jinja Shrine and Shingu-jinja Shrine were built in the precincts.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, in 902 Wakamiya-jinja Shrine was built and in 1190 Imamiya-jinja Shrine and Shingu-jinja Shrine were built in the precincts.
After that, in 902 Wakamiya-jinja Shrine was built and in 1190 Imamiya-jinja Shrine and Shingu-jinja Shrine were built in the precincts.

sen.j: 中世には五社大権現ともよばれ信仰を集めた。
sen.e: During the medieval period, the five shrines were called Gosha Daigongen (the Great Avatar of five shrines) and became very popular.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the medieval period, the five shrines were called Gosha Daigongen (the Great Avatar of five shrines) and became very popular.
During the medieval period, the five shrines were called Gosha Daigongen (the Great Avatar of five shrines) and became very popular.

sen.j: 小椋神社の社名はいつしか田所神社となっていたが、昭和20年（1945年）現在の社名に戻された。
sen.e: The name of Ogura-jinja Shrine changed into Tadokoro-jinja Shrine over the course of time, but the name of the shrine was returned to the current one.
The name of Ogura-jinja Shrine changed into Tadokoro-jinja Shrine over the course of time, but the name of the shrine was returned to the current one.
The name of Ogura-jinja Shrine changed into Tadokoro-jinja Shrine over the course of time, but the name of the shrine was returned to the current one.

sen.j: 祭礼
sen.e: The rites and festivals
The rites and festivals
The rites and festivals

sen.j: 例祭は5月3日に行われ、仰木祭りと称される。
sen.e: The festival of the shrine is held on May 3, and it is called Ogi Festival.
The festival of the shrine is held on May 3, and it is called Ogi Festival.
The festival of the shrine is held on May 3, and it is called Ogi Festival.

sen.j: また、例年雨天が多く神輿の通った後が泥田のようになったため、泥田祭りともよばれる。
sen.e: In addition, as it rains much at this time of the year and the paths of the portable shrine become muddy like rice fields, it is called Dorota (muddy rice fields) Festival.
In addition, as it rains much at this time of the year and the paths of the portable shrine become muddy like rice fields, it is called Dorota (muddy rice fields) Festival.
In addition, as it rains much at this time of the year and the paths of the portable shrine become muddy like rice fields, it is called Dorota (muddy rice fields) Festival.

sen.j: 平安時代後期に仰木に移り住んだ清和源氏の二代、源満仲公を偲ぶ古式行事が行われ、流鏑馬、五社の神輿が巡幸が行われる。
sen.e: Some ancient events including yabusame (horseback archery) and the parade of the portable shrines of the five shrines to commemorate MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, the second generation of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa) are held.

Some ancient events including yabusame (horseback archery) and the parade of the portable shrines of the five shrines to commemorate MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, the second generation of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa) are held.
sen.cmt: スペースを修正しました。
sen.e: Some ancient events including yabusame (horseback archery) and the parade of the portable shrines of the five shrines to commemorate MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, the second generation of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa) are held.
